talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

item.para: How many (a) male, and (b) female clients of the Child Support Agency (CSA) in the electoral divisions of (i) Lindsay, (ii) Prospect, (iii) Greenway, (iv) Mitchell, (v) Parramatta, (vi) Fowler, (vii) Hughes, (viii) Reid, (ix) Macquarie, (x) Macarthur, and (xi) Werriwa receive a Child Support Liability.

How many (a) male, and (b) female clients of the CSA in the electoral divisions of (i) Lindsay, (ii) Prospect, (iii) Greenway, (iv) Mitchell, (v) Parramatta, (vi) Fowler, (vii) Hughes, (viii) Reid, (ix) Macquarie, (x) Macarthur, and (xi) Werriwa receive a Child Support Payment.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Only payers with postcodes have been allocated to electorates. Furthermore some payees have postcodes which are not included in the list of postcodes assigned to electorates supplied by the Parliamentary Library. This list does not include mail centres.
CSA does not have reliable gender data available. Instead, payers and payees are offered as an alternative. Approximately 89% of payers are male and approximately 89% of payees are female.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 29 November 2004:

item.para: How many people have taken up the Governmentâs Pension Bonus Scheme in (a) Australia, and (b) in the postcode are (i) 3130, (ii) 3131, (iii) 3132, (iv) 3133, (v) 3134, (vi) 3151, and (vii) 3136.
How many people have been excluded from the scheme after it commenced due to lack of continuity.
How does the performance of the scheme compare to original targets.
How many representations has he received from Commonwealth Members of Parliament about the Pension Bonus Scheme since its inception.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The number of people that have taken up the Governmentâs Pension Bonus Scheme in (a) Australia, and (b) in the postcode area (i) 3130, (ii) 3131, (iii) 3132, (iv) 3133, (v) 3134, (vi) 3151, and (vii) 3136 is shown in the following table:

quote.para: Note: Data source date is 15 December 2004.

item.para: The number of people who have been excluded from receiving the Pension Bonus is 2,522 (as at 15 December 2004). Reasons for exclusion include:

quote.para: -Â Â Â Â Â Â not residentially qualified,
-Â Â Â Â Â Â not age qualified,
-Â Â Â Â Â Â no pension payable,
-Â Â Â Â Â Â failed the work test.

item.para: Centrelink is generally able to backdate registrations where the customer states they were unaware of the Pension Bonus Scheme or the requirement to register.

(3)Â Â Take-up of the scheme has been lower than originally forecast in the 1997-98 Budget. However, the take-up of the scheme is substantial â almost one-fifth of people of ageÂ pensionÂ age who are working are registered in the scheme. A further one-third receive Age Pension and concessions while they work.

The take-up has been affected by changes made to the social security system since the scheme commenced. As part of the Governmentâs tax reform package, the social security income test taper rate has been reduced from 50 per cent to 40 per cent since July 2000, and the rate of pension has increased through a one-off adjustment over and above the usual indexation arrangements for the same period. These changes have made it relatively more attractive for people of Age Pension age who are working to claim a part pension and pensioner concessions while they work.

(4)Â Â Minister Hockey has received four (4) representations in relation to the Pension Bonus Scheme since his appointment as Minister for Human Services. However, since inception of the Pension Bonus Scheme, Centrelink has received 149 representations from Commonwealth Members of Parliament. Since 11 December 2002 the Department of Family and Community Services has received 186 representations of which 75 were received from Commonwealth Members of Parliament. Department of Family and Community Services data prior to 11 December 2002 has been archived and is not available.

quote.para: Note: Data source date is 15 December 2004.

item.para: The number of people who have been excluded from receiving the Pension Bonus is 2,522 (as at 15 December 2004). Reasons for exclusion include:

quote.para: -Â Â Â Â Â Â not residentially qualified,
-Â Â Â Â Â Â not age qualified,
-Â Â Â Â Â Â no pension payable,
-Â Â Â Â Â Â failed the work test.

item.para: Centrelink is generally able to backdate registrations where the customer states they were unaware of the Pension Bonus Scheme or the requirement to register.

(3)Â Â Take-up of the scheme has been lower than originally forecast in the 1997-98 Budget. However, the take-up of the scheme is substantial â almost one-fifth of people of ageÂ pensionÂ age who are working are registered in the scheme. A further one-third receive Age Pension and concessions while they work.

The take-up has been affected by changes made to the social security system since the scheme commenced. As part of the Governmentâs tax reform package, the social security income test taper rate has been reduced from 50 per cent to 40 per cent since July 2000, and the rate of pension has increased through a one-off adjustment over and above the usual indexation arrangements for the same period. These changes have made it relatively more attractive for people of Age Pension age who are working to claim a part pension and pensioner concessions while they work.

(4)Â Â Minister Hockey has received four (4) representations in relation to the Pension Bonus Scheme since his appointment as Minister for Human Services. However, since inception of the Pension Bonus Scheme, Centrelink has received 149 representations from Commonwealth Members of Parliament. Since 11 December 2002 the Department of Family and Community Services has received 186 representations of which 75 were received from Commonwealth Members of Parliament. Department of Family and Community Services data prior to 11 December 2002 has been archived and is not available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 29 November 2004:

item.para: Is he aware that the Child Support Agency allows paying parents to inform it of a change of income and circumstances by telephone and that this may result in a change to the paying parentâs liability.
Is he also aware that should the receiving parent object to a change in assessment that has resulted from information received orally, that parent must object in writing.
Will he address this inconsistency of approach to paying and receiving parents.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: CSA accepts most information and advice over the telephone from either parent.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â This includes the original application for an assessment of child support, as well as any changes in circumstances that either parent advises CSA about. Accepting information over the telephone is the most effective and efficient way to deliver child support services to parents, and is the least onerous for parents.
Either parent must object in writing if they wish to challenge a CSA decision. This is a legislative requirement.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â However, the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 that was introduced into Parliament on 8 December 2004, contains an amendment that would remove the requirement for this to be in writing. It would enable CSA to accept objections by telephone.

There is no inconsistency. The process for providing verbal information and for objecting in writing is the same for both parents. The amendment in the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 removing the requirement for objections to be in writing would assist all parents.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 29 November 2004:

item.para: Is he aware that the Child Support Agency from time to time receives information from paying parentsâ employers about termination and other changes to employment that would affect the paying parentâs income.

Following receipt of this information, does the Child Support Agency routinely contact paying parents to remind than of their obligations to formally inform the Agency of a change in their circumstances; if not, will he direct the Child Support Agency to contact paying parents on each occasion such information from employers is received

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

The Child Support Agency (CSA) routinely reminds parents of their obligations to inform the Agency of changes in circumstances which affect their child support entitlement or liability. This information is included in the Child Support Handbook provided to all new clients and included on a flyer which is sent out with statements of account. The CSA website also reminds parents that they should inform the Agency of changes in their circumstances. Client Service Officers also reinforce this message when talking to parents. Where CSA becomes aware of a change in circumstances which may change the amount of child support payable, the CSA contacts the parents and works with them to ensure that the child support assessment is correct and that every appropriate option for both parents has been explored.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 29 November 2004:

item.para: For each year since 2000, how many (a) general practitioners, (b) other Medicare providers, and (c) specialists were practising in the electoral division of Corio.

For each year since 2000, what was the ratio of (a) general practitioners, (b) other Medicare providers, and (c) specialists per 1000 head of population ratio for (i) Australia, (ii) Victoria, and (iii) the electoral division of Corio.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: (b) and (c) Medicare Provider workforce statistics are compiled on a Financial Year basis and are derived on the basis of servicing provider postcode. The numbers of General Practitioners and Specialists who practiced in the electoral division of Corio were as follows:

entry.para: Number of Medicare Providers in the Federal Electorate of Corio

quote.para: It should be noted that the simple headcounts given above do not account for differences in the number of services claimed and will include a high proportion of casual and part-time practitioners. Therefore they do not accurately represent the supply of doctors.

A more accurate statistic is the Full-Time Equivalent, which is a standardised measure to estimate the number of full-time doctors which adjusts for the partial contribution of casual and part-time doctors. The Full-Time Equivalent numbers of General Practitioners and Specialists who practiced in the electoral division of Corio were as follows:

entry.para: Full-Time Equivalent number of Medicare Providers in the Federal Electorate of Corio

quote.para: The ratios for Australia, Victoria and the Corio electorate are as follows.

entry.para: Ratio of population to Full-Time Equivalent providers in Australia

quote.para: Statistical Notes

These statistics relate to all providers of at least one service on a âfee-for-serviceâ basis and for which Medicare benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in the years in question. Excluded are details of services to public patients in hospital, to Department of Veteransâ Affairs patients and some compensation cases.

The simple headcounts given above do not account for differences in the number of services claimed and will include a high proportion of casual and part-time practitioners. Therefore it will not accurately represent the supply of doctors.

It is for this reason that âFull-Time Equivalentâ (FTE) practitioner is the statistic used in the population ratios given above. FTE is a standardised measure to estimate the number of full-time doctors which adjusts for the partial contribution of casual and part-time doctors. FTE is calculated by dividing each doctorâs Medicare billing by the average billing of full-time doctors for the reference period. Where the doctorâs Medicare billing is greater than or equal to the mean billing of full-time doctors, then the FTE is capped at one.

In general terms, practitioners with at least 50% of Schedule fee income from non-referred (GP) attendances in the June quarter of the years in question were considered to be General Practitioners. All other practitioners, including optometrists and some dentists who provided services under Medicare, were categorised as âSpecialists.â

These statistics were compiled from Medicare data on the basis of servicing provider postcode. In compiling statistics for Federal electoral division boundaries, statistics by servicing provider postcode were mapped to electorate according to the proportion of the population of each postcode in each Federal electoral division.
State-level statistics were compiled by allocating each postcode to a single state only. National statistics are the aggregate of all providers.

The electorate populations used in Population to FTE ratios were supplied as a special order by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The state and national populations used were obtained from the Australian Bureau of Statisticsâ June 2004 âAustralian Demographic Statisticsâ cat no. 3101.0.

It should be noted that the simple headcounts given above do not account for differences in the number of services claimed and will include a high proportion of casual and part-time practitioners. Therefore they do not accurately represent the supply of doctors.

A more accurate statistic is the Full-Time Equivalent, which is a standardised measure to estimate the number of full-time doctors which adjusts for the partial contribution of casual and part-time doctors. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 30 November 2004:

item.para: What evidence is there to justify his recent statements that claim poor literacy levels among Australian school children.
Where is Australia placed on the most recent OECD comparison on national literacy levels.
Where is Australia placed on the most recent comparative statistics on national literacy levels.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Results from the 2001 National Report on Schooling in Australia show that for reading 10% of Year 3 students and 10% of Year 5 students failed to achieve the national reading benchmark.Â

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Some groups of students had even greater difficulty achieving reading benchmarks.Â For example, 12% of boys in Year 3 and 12% of boys in Year 5 failed to achieve the national reading benchmarks.Â Literacy levels among Indigenous students are cause for real concern with only 72% in Year 3 and 67% in Year 5 achieving the national reading benchmarks.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â The Australian Government has enshrined in legislation the target that all Year 3 children should achieve benchmark standards in reading from 2001 on, recognising that the benchmarks represent minimum levels of achievement required to enable students to progress their schooling.Â Under the proposed arrangements for the new quadrennial funding agreement for 2005-2008, education authorities will be required to make additional commitments so that all children in Year 5 and Year 7 are expected to achieve the relevant reading benchmarks with the same proviso recognising that a very small percentage of students have severe educational disabilities and may not achieve the benchmark standards.Â As a condition of funding, all education authorities are required to commit to achieving performance targets in the legislation.Â

Results from the OECD Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) in 2003 for 15 year-olds in the 41 countries that participated indicate that Australia had the fourth highest mean score for reading literacy.Â The OECD has estimated that Australia ranks between 3rd and 5th among OECD countries and between 3rd and 6th among all participating countries.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Despite our high performance overall, the results also show that there are still too many Australian students performing at the lowest levels measured by PISA.Â In reading, more than one in ten of our students achieved only at the two lowest levels of proficiency. As PISA reported, these students are âat risk of not acquiring essential life skills, partly because they do not have the foundation of literacy skills needed for continued learning and extending their knowledge horizonâ.Â

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Boysâ reading achievement is significantly lower than that for girls, as occurs in all OECD countries.Â There was a large performance difference in reading literacy achievement between Indigenous students and non-Indigenous students with 38% of Indigenous students performing at Level 1 or Below Level 1.Â

The final report of the latest available International Adult Literacy Survey (OECD Statistics Canada 2000) shows that Australia places around 10th in comparative distributions prepared by the OECD of the literacy levels of 22 countries.Â Australia is ranked behind Canada and ahead of UK, US and New Zealand.Â

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 30 November 2004:

Note 2: The categories of people who receive Health Care Cards are people on low incomes, foster children, certain disabled children, and former long-term unemployed income support recipients who have obtained employment (such customers can retain their card for six (6) months after entering employment, to ease the transition from welfare to work).

Note 3: The data is based on the number of cards issued that remain current and have not yet reached their expiry date. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 2 December 2004:

item.para: Which clauses of the ANZUS alliance are inconsistent with the ASEAN Treaty of Amity and Cooperation.
Which countries which are not members of ASEAN have signed the Treaty.

Can he say whether any ASEAN member states or external signatories have (a)Â criticised Myanmar or other member states for human rights abuses, and (b)Â commented on a member stateâs domestic affairs.

Are the terms of the Five Power Defence Arrangement consistent with the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation; if not, what aspects are at variance; if they are consistent, can he explain how the Five Power Defence Arrangement can be consistent with the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation whilst ANZUS is not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: I direct the Honorable Member to my answer in the House of Representatives on 29 November 2004.
To date, China, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Russia, Pakistan and India have signed the ASEAN Treaty of Amity and Cooperation.
Comments by signatories to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation are matters for them.

There is no formal plurilateral treaty between the five countries (Malaysia, Singapore, United Kingdom, New Zealand and Australia) of what is known as the Five Power Defence Arrangement. As a former Defence Minister I would have thought the Member would have known this.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 6 December 2004:

item.para: What sum has his department spent on the McKinnon case which relates to government legal advice on whether Mr David Hicks is legally held by the Government of the United States of America.
Has his department received any legal advice supporting the release to MrÂ McKinnon of some or any of the documents that are still being withheld in that case.

Is it the case that during the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) hearing into McKinnon and his department, the AAT heard that Mr Hicks was a special case and had been denied consular support by his department; if so, what are the details of other occasions where Australian citizens have been treated as âspecial casesâ by the Australian Government and denied consular support.

Does the issuing of a conclusive certificate require the appropriate Minister personally to inspect each document covered by the certificate before issuing it; if so, when did he carry out such an exercise and how long did he take to review the documents in dispute.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: $175,978 (GST exclusive) has been spent on the McKinnon FOI litigation to 15 December 2004.
No.

Levels of consular access and service provided to Australians overseas depend on the nature of the arrest and detention. A range of services have been provided, including ascertaining Mr Hicksâ welfare, ensuring access to medical services, facilitating communication with his parents, and seeking to ensure that the process to which he is subject is undertaken expeditiously.

The Freedom of Information Act 1982 requires a Minister to be satisfied that each document (or part of document) is exempt from release prior to issuing a conclusive certificate. In this matter, the Minister for Foreign Affairs inspected the relevant documents on a number of separate occasions and is satisfied that the documents are exempt (in whole or in part).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 6 December 2004:

item.para: How many (a) in total, (b) sole parents, and (c) Disability Support Pensioners in the electoral division of Fowler were recipients of the Pensioner Education Supplement at 30 June 2004.

How many Youth Allowance recipients in the electoral division of Fowler were undertaking (a) secondary studies, (b) tertiary studies at a university, and (c) tertiary or post-secondary studies at another approved education institution at 30 June 2004.

How many Austudy recipients in the electoral division of Fowler were attending (a) primary school, (b) secondary school, (c) another approved education institution, and (d) undertaking postgraduate studies at 30 June 2004.

How many Abstudy recipients in the electoral division of Fowler were attending (a) primary school, (b) secondary school, (c) another approved education institution, and (d) undertaking postgraduate studies at 30 June 2004.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: As at 30 June 2004, in the electoral division of Fowler, 255 Centrelink customers were recipients of the Pensioner Education Supplement, 122 were sole parents receiving the Pensioner Education Supplement and 59 were Disability Support Pensioners receiving the Pensioner Education Supplement.

As at 30 June 2004, in the electoral division of Fowler, 1,762 Youth Allowance recipients were undertaking secondary studies, 915 youth Allowance recipients were undertaking tertiary studies at a university and 364 youth Allowance recipients were tertiary or post-secondary studies at another approved education institution.

As at 30 June 2004, in the electoral division of Fowler, less than 20 Austudy recipients were attending primary school, less than 20 Austudy recipients were attending secondary school, 159 Austudy recipients were attending another approved institution and less than 20 were undertaking postgraduate studies.

As at 30 June 2004, in the electoral division of Fowler, less than 20 Abstudy recipients were attending primary school, 103 were attending secondary school, 33 were attending another approved institution and less than 20 were undertaking postgraduate studies.

quote.para: Note 1: Where requested data reveals customer numbers of less than 20, the actual number of recipients is not identified to prevent identification of individuals as required by Privacy Law.
Note 2: The computer software used to identify customers by electorate is accurate to +/- 10%.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 7 December 2004:

item.para: What sum was provided for 2004 to (a) government and (b) non-government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith and in the postcode area (i) 2019, (ii) 2036, (iii) 2031, (iv) 2034, (v) 2032, (vi) 2018, (vii) 2036, (viii) 2035, (ix) 2020, and (x) 2052.
What was the (a) expenditure on, (b) location of, and (c) purpose of each grant in 2004.

What sum will be provided for 2005 to (a) government, and (b) non-government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith and in the postcode area (i) 2019, (ii) 2036, (iii) 2031, (iv) 2034, (v) 2032, (vi) 2018, (vii) 2036, (viii) 2035, (ix) 2020, and (x) 2052 for 2005.
What will (a) the expenditure be for, (b) be the location of, and (c) be the purpose of each grant in 2005.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for government schools is not reported at the level of detail requested. Australian Government General Recurrent Grants for government schools are provided to the government education authority in each State or Territory, on the basis of total enrolments. The State or Territory determines where the grants are used. Payments to individual schools are not recorded.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â The Department of Education, Science and Training only provides electoral division and postcode detail for General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools and Capital Grants to both government and non-government schools. For this period, no Capital Grants funding was provided to government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith or identified postcodes for 2004.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for non-government schools cannot be reported at the level of detail requested. Funding from Australian Government programmes that can be reported at this level of detail totalled $28,016,356 in 2004 for non-government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith and the identified postcodes, with $27,691,356 from the General Recurrent Grants programme and $325,000 from the Capital Grants programme.

(2)Â Â (a), (b) Details on the expenditure and location of Capital Grants to non-government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith or identified postcodes for 2004 are in Table 1 at Attachment A. Details on the expenditure and location of General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith or identified postcodes for 2004 for this period are in Table 2 at Attachment A.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: , (b) Details on the expenditure and location of Capital Grants to non-government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith or identified postcodes for 2004 are in Table 1 at Attachment A. Details on the expenditure and location of General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith or identified postcodes for 2004 for this period are in Table 2 at Attachment A.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The purpose of the Australian Government Capital Grants is to provide education outcomes by assisting in the provision of school facilities, particularly in ways that contribute most to raising the overall level of educational achievement of Australian school students.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â The purpose of Australian Government General Recurrent Grants is to help schools with the recurrent cost of school education so that they can offer students educational s directed towards the achievement of the Australian Governmentâs priorities for schooling.

(3)Â Â (a) Estimates of total Australian Government funding for 2005 for government schools are not maintained at the level of detail requested (see response to 1a). Information about 2005 Capital Grants for government schools is not yet available.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: Estimates of total Australian Government funding for 2005 for government schools are not maintained at the level of detail requested (see response to 1a). Information about 2005 Capital Grants for government schools is not yet available.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Estimates of total Australian Government funding for 2005 for non-government schools are not maintained at the level of detail requested. However it is estimated that $32,539,710 will be provided in 2005 under the General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith and the identified postcodes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Information about 2005 Capital Grants for non-government schools is not available.

(4)Â Â (a), (b)Details on the estimated expenditure and location of General Recurrent Grants for non-government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith and the identified postcodes for this period are in Table 3 at Attachment A.

item.label: (4) (a)
item.para: , (b)Details on the estimated expenditure and location of General Recurrent Grants for non-government schools in the electoral division of Kingsford Smith and the identified postcodes for this period are in Table 3 at Attachment A.

item.label: (c)
item.para: See response to (2c).

Note 3: The categories of people who receive Health Care Cards are people on low incomes, foster children, certain disabled children, and former long-term unemployed income support recipients who have obtained employment (such customers can retain their card for six (6) months after entering employment, to ease the transition from welfare to work).

Note 4: The data is based on the number of cards issued that remain current and have not yet reached their expiry date. Due to recent system enhancements, these data no longer include cancelled cards, and are therefore a more accurate reflection of actual Health Care Card numbers than data provided prior to 1 July 2004.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 8Â December 2004:

item.para: For each financial year since 1996-1997, how many search warrants were obtained under section 101X of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982.

In respect of each warrant in part (1), (a) what alleged offence were specified in the warrant, (b) where were the warrants executed (i.e. on a ship, aircraft or vehicle; military, naval or air base; other Department of Defence property; private residence or other place), and (c) how many persons were (i) charged with, and (ii) convicted of, an offence or offences under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 following the execution of a search warrant or warrants.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: The Navy and the Air Force do not maintain a central search warrant register or database.Â To collect and assemble such information solely for the purpose of answering the question would be a major task, and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure and effort that would be required.Â The answers provided below are for the Army which does maintain a central register.
ARMY

damage to service property;
dangerous conduct;
disobey lawful general order;
drug abuse;
failure to comply with a lawful general order;

fraud;
making false entry in service document;
making false service document;

obstruct service police;
offences based on territorial offences/act of indecency;
possession of cannabis in Australia;
using cannabis.
prejudicial behaviour;
prejudicial conduct;
theft; and
unlawful possession.

The warrants were executed on private motor vehicles, private and service residences, military bases, Department of Defence medical facilities, livingâin accommodation and civilian places of business.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on Thursday, 9 December 2004:

item.para: What sum was provided for 2004 to (a) government and (b) non-government schools in the electoral division of Lowe and in the postcode area (i) 2045, (ii) 2046, (iii) 2047, (iv) 2131, (v) 2132, (vi)2133, (vii) 2134, (viii) 2135, (ix) 2136, (x) 2137, (xi) 2138, and (xii) 2140.
What was the (a) expenditure on, (b) location of, and (c) purpose of each grant in 2004.

What sum will be provided for 2005 to (a) government and (b) non-government schools in the electoral division of Lowe and in the postcode area (i) 2045, (ii) 2046, (iii) 2047, (iv) 2131, (v) 2132, (vi) 2133, (vii) 2134, (viii) 2135, (ix) 2136, (x) 2137, (xi) 2138, and (xii) 2140 for 2005.
What will (a) the expenditure be for, (b) be the location of, and (c) be the purpose of each grant in 2005.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for government schools is not reported at the level of detail requested. Australian Government General Recurrent Grants for government schools are provided to the government education authority in each State or Territory, on the basis of total enrolments. The State or Territory determines where the grants are used. Payments to individual schools are not recorded.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â The Department of Education, Science and Training only provides electoral division and postcode detail for General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools and Capital Grants to both government and non-government schools. For this period, $1,150,000 was provided to government schools in the electoral division of Lowe or identified postcodes from the Capital Grants Programme.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for non-government schools cannot be reported at the level of detail requested. Funding from Australian Government programmes that can be reported at this level of detail totalled $54,439,930 in 2004 for non-government schools in the electoral division of Lowe and the identified postcodes, from the General Recurrent Grants programme. No Capital Grants funding was provided in 2004 to non-government schools in the electoral division of Lowe or identified postcodes.

(2)Â Â (a), (b)Details on the expenditure and location of Capital Grants to government schools in the electoral division of Lowe or identified postcodes for 2004 are in Table 1 at Attachment A. Details on the expenditure and location of General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools in the electoral division of Lowe or identified postcodes for 2004 for this period are in Table 2 at Attachment A.

Details on the expenditure and location of General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools in the electoral division of Lowe or identified postcodes for 2004 for this period are in Table 2 at Attachment A.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The purpose of the Australian Government Capital Grants is to provide education outcomes by assisting in the provision of school facilities, particularly in ways that contribute most to raising the overall level of educational achievement of Australian school students.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â The purpose of Australian Government General Recurrent Grants is to help schools with the recurrent cost of school education so that they can offer students educational s directed towards the achievement of the Australian Governmentâs priorities for schooling.

(3)Â Â (a) Estimates of total Australian Government funding for 2005 for government schools are not maintained at the level of detail requested (see response to 1a). Information about 2005 Capital Grants for government schools is not yet available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 8 February 2005:

item.para: In respect of the reference on page 34 of the Australian Customs Service (ACS) report for 2003-2004, can the Minister explain which activities of the ACS are (a) prioritised as âcore activitiesâ, (b) considered to be of a âlower priority and minimal impact on border securityâ, and (c) classified as âenforcement operationsâ.

In respect of those activities classified as core activities since 2002, (a) how many (i) full-time, and (ii) part-time staff were reallocated within the ACS to perform these core activities, (b) what are their current broadband classifications, (c) how many are (i) on-going, and (ii) non-ongoing, (d) what are their job titles, and (e) from which activity (whether core or otherwise) was each staff member reallocated.

Since 2002, (a) how many (i) full-time, and (ii) part-time staff were reallocated within ACS to perform first-port boarding of commercial vessels (and any affiliated activities supporting first-port boarding of commercial vessels in an operational capacity), (b) what are their current broadband classifications, (c) how many are (i) on-going, and (ii) non-ongoing, (d) what are their job titles, and (e) from which activity (whether core or otherwise) was each staff member reallocated.
On what specific items will the $2.8 million allocated for 2004-2005 to increase first-port boarding be spent.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The Australian Customs Service (Customs) core activities carried out by the Enforcement Operations Branch are:
the clearance of all maritime traffic to and from Australia in relation to the vessels, crew and passengers;
response action to vessels or crew assessed as posing a terrorism risk or other threats to the border; and
waterfront security/patrol.
Activities considered to be of a lower priority and minimal impact on border security are, in the absence of any intelligence:
land based surveillance, ie remote area patrols;
visits to and liaison with Customs Frontline and Hotline contacts;
response to vessels not assessed as posing a terrorism risk or other threats to the border; and
deployment of enforcement officers (non National Marine Unit) on Australian Customs Vessels engaged in routine Customs or client taskings.
Enforcement operations refers to the Branch of Customs responsible for activities outlined in the answer to question (1)(a).

item.label: (a)
item.para: (ii) Customs data is expressed in terms of full time equivalent staff as per the table below.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Customs level 1 and Customs level 2.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (c)Â Â (i) All are on-going.

item.label: (i)
item.para: All are on-going.
Not applicable.
Customs does not use job titles in describing these functions.
Remote District Offices cut back on the activities outlined in response to Question 1(b). Staff were redeployed largely from the Compliance function in capital cities.
Staff involved in first port boarding of commercial vessels and affiliated activities supporting this are outlined in the answer provided in response to Question (2).

The $2.8 million is to cover the cost of an extra 19 staff deployed at 11 locations. It is comprised of departmental expenses for staff and property operating expenses for accommodation and office build/refurbishment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 8 February 2005:

quote.para: Has a commercial-sized neutron scanner been installed at Brisbane airport; if so, (a) when was it installed, (b)Â what sum was allocated for the scanner in the 2003-2004 budget, (c) what was the actual cost of the scanner, and (d) what was the estimated total cost of a field trial of the scanner; if not, when will a scanner be installed.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The scanner has not been installed at Brisbane airport.Â The scanner is being built by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and construction of a facility to house the scanner and other associated equipment commenced in late 2004 at Brisbane Airport.Â The scanner is due to be installed and commissioned in the second half of 2005.Â

item.label: (b)
item.para: No funds were allocated to this project in the 2003-2004 Budget.Â Funding was allocated for the scanner and field trial in the 2004-2005 Budget as follows: $5.6 million in 2004-2005 and $2.8 million in 2005-2006.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The actual cost of the scanner unit will be $2.9 million.Â This is the cost of the scanner only and does not include necessary fit-out such as radiation shielding.

item.label: (d)
item.para: The total amount allocated to the field trial, including the scanner unit and depreciation, is $8.4 million.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 8 February 2005:

item.para: Has the Australian Customs Service developed an integrated succession and career management strategy; if so, when was or will this strategy be implemented.
Is there a policy or procedure to review the effectiveness of the strategy; if so, what are the details; if not, when will one be introduced.
Was there any employee participation in the development of the strategy; if so, what was the nature and extent of this participation.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Customs is in the final stages of developing an integrated succession and career management program. The program was developed in response to a number of factors including Australian Public Service Commission papers (APSC) indicating the need for agencies to give greater attention to succession management and feedback from staff indicating a greater need for career development and assistance.Â Customs already has an integrated approach to Workforce Planning and an Assignment and Career management Policy and a succession management program will compliment these existing approaches.Â The program consists of an informative Policy Advice and, a Toolkit to help managers with their work areaâs succession needs and staff to better manage their careers.Â The program will be incorporated into each Customs regionâs career assignment process over the period February to June 2005.

An evaluation of the program will be scheduled following the implementation of the program through a full Performance Assessment and Feedback cycle (at this stage July 2006). It is anticipated that the data collection and reporting aspects of the information management system may need to be modified to support the career and succession management process across Customs.

The program was developed using information obtained from a survey of Customs regions, a workshop of Customs Human Resource Managers, interviews with operational managers and comments received from Customs Corporate Support Managers.Â

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 8 February 2005:

item.para: Has his department implemented all of the 66 recommendations contained in the COAG report Natural disasters in Australia: Reforming mitigation, relief and recovery arrangements; if not, which recommendations have not been implemented.
Has his department taken any steps to implement those recommendations that have not been implemented; if so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: No. Responsibility for implementing the 66 recommendations contained in the COAG report falls to Australian, State, Territory and Local Governments, and to the private sector.Â

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A key recommendation of the COAG report was the establishment of a Ministerial Council to oversee national emergency management arrangements and implementation of the Natural Disaster Reform Package. This has been implemented with the establishment of the Augmented Australasian Police Ministersâ Council (A/APMC), and the re-constitution of the Australian Emergency Management Committee.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â The A/APMC has oversight of all 66 recommendations, and has its inaugural meeting on 4 March 2005. All jurisdictions will report progress on implementation of the COAG recommendations at this meeting

No. The Australian Government does not have the authority to act in areas for which State, Territory, Local Governments or non-government agencies are responsible, but is working in partnership with them to implement the COAG recommendations.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 8 February 2005:

item.para: Has the department developed branch/plans and section/team plans as identified on page 118 of its report for 2003-2004; if not, when will they be developed.
Has the department aligned individual performance agreements to the plans; if not, when will it do so.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Attorney-Generalâs Department Annual Report 2003â04 referred to a review of the Departmentâs corporate performance management framework on page 118.Â That review recommended developments to the existing framework and processes that would enable more consistent planning approaches across the Department.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â I am advised that the first stage was to conduct a trial of a revised planning process (based on a modified balanced scorecard approach) in the Departmentâs Corporate Services Group (CSG).Â That trial commenced with the development of a business plan for the Group.Â That plan forms the basis of a series of cascading branch plans and section/team plans that reflect the goals and priorities set in the higher level plan.Â Some of those lower level plans have been developed using the new approach while others are currently in development. The remaining plans for CSG will be completed during 2005.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â At the Groupâs most recent performance review by the Departmentâs Executive, the new CSG business plan was used to assess the Groupâs achievements against planned business strategies.Â Once the full set of CSG plans have been developed and in use for another reporting cycle, an evaluation will be conducted to determine the suitability of the modified approach from a whole-of-Department perspective.

I am advised that, in keeping with the Departmentâs integrated approach to performance management, individual performance agreements with staff are to be aligned with the Departmentâs goals, expressed in successive levels of division/office business plans, branch plans and section/team plans.Â In this way there is a clear link between the planned activities of individual staff and the organisationâs goals.Â This linkage occurs with the plans and agreements prepared under the current performance framework.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â In the case of the CSG trial referred to in part (1) of the response above, where the lower level plans have been developed using the new approach, individualsâ performance agreements have been, or are in the process of being, aligned to the plans.Â Performance agreements for other staff can be aligned when the respective plans for that area have been developed according to the new approach.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 8 February 2005:

item.para: What gaps did his department identify in emergency management competency standards during 2003-2004 as noted on page 103 of its report for 2003-2004.
What amendments or alterations have been made to emergency management competency standards to address each gap.
Was his department aware at any time prior to 2003-2004 of the existence of any gaps.

Has his department conducted a review of emergency management competency standards prior to 2003-2004; if so, did it identify gaps similar or identical to gaps that were identified in 2003-2004 and if it did what were they.
Did his department make any amendments or alterations prior to 2003-2004 to emergency management competency standards to address any gaps.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The gaps were identified through a 2001-02 scoping project conducted by the Public Safety Training Industry Advisory Body (PSITAB). The gaps identified were (a) emergency planning, (b) evacuation, and (c) lower level competency standards in emergency risk management to provide pathways into higher level competencies
In partnership with the PSITAB, Emergency Management Australia (EMA) in 2003 consulted with key stakeholders at all levels of government and non-government organisations (NGOs) to:

item.label: (a)
item.para: develop a new competency standard Undertake emergency planning

review the need for a competency standard for evacuation â it was identified that planning for evacuation is covered by the new unit Undertake emergency planning and that effecting an evacuation is covered by the existing competency standards for command and control.Â Minor additions were suggested to the range of variables to make the command and control standards more explicit.

(c)Â Â develop lower level competency standards in emergency risk management to provide pathways into higher level competencies â a new competency standard was developed to describe the knowledge and skills required by people who contribute to the emergency risk management process in their community. The higher level standards in emergency risk management were reviewed and amended to ensure consistency with knowledge gained from the implementation of emergency risk management.
Yes. As answered in response to Question 1.

Yes. EMA managed a project to develop competency standards for emergency management in 1995. These were overtaken by the introduction of the National Training Framework and the move away from a hazards approach to a risk based approach to emergency management.Â

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â The Public Safety Industry Training Package that includes competency standards for emergency management, including risk management, was developed by the PSITAB and endorsed by the former Ministerial Council of the Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) in July 2000.Â Â

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â During 2002-03, EMA progressively developed training and assessment programs to achieve the emergency management competency standards, and during this process confirmed deficiencies already identified through the PSITAB scoping project undertaken in 2001-02.Â Â

Yes. EMA was actively involved in the move from the 1995 standards to the 2000 version.Â The later version has broader applicability across the Public Safety Industry and supports the implementation of a risk based, community centred approach to emergency risk management.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 8 February 2005:

item.para: When was the most recent performance review of organisational elements conducted by his department.

In respect of the last review, (a) how did organisational performance compare to business/operational plan performance measures, (b) in relation to routine activities, how did organisational performance compare to departmental performance standards.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: I am advised that the Department continually reviews its performance.Â Key elements of this process are:
weekly meetings of the Departmentâs Executive Committee

monthly consideration by the Executive of key departmental performance data (covering financial, staffing, ministerial and parliamentary services, internal security, information and knowledge services, and FOI matters, as well as implementation of budget/major initiatives and other key matters), with quarterly reports containing more detailed staffing data
program of twice-yearly reviews by the Executive of each organisational element of the Department, supported by division/group business plans and agreed work programs
ongoing internal review by line areas of achievements against lower level business plans and agreed work programs
review and evaluation of specific projects or activities, and
twice-yearly reviews of individual performance against each staff memberâs performance agreement, as part of the Program for Performance Improvement.

quote.para: In addition there are regular meetings of senior departmental officials with myself and the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Ellison, to determine priorities, or to discuss specific and/or emerging issues.Â These processes are supplemented from time to time by special meetings/conferences of the Departmentâs senior staff to discuss particular issues.

item.para: Each year the Department assesses performance of organisational elements against the performance information set out in the Portfolio Budget Statements, for the purposes of preparing the Annual Report.

quote.para: In relation to the Executive performance reviews, the senior management team from each division and office and each supporting group (Corporate Services Group and Information and Knowledge Services Group) is scheduled to appear before the Executive twice a year, approximately six months apart.Â These reviews are spread across the year, usually from early February to early December, rather than in a set short timeframe each six months.

The most recent review of organisational elements scheduled to appear before the Executive occurred late last year, over the period August -â November 2004.Â The annual assessment for annual report preparation purposes occurred over the period June â August 2004.

item.para: I am advised that in relation to the Executive performance reviews, the Executive is apprised of the progress on the agreed work program in the supporting business/operational plan for the organisational element concerned, and there is the opportunity to discuss a range of matters including variations in priorities, risk assessments, expenditure against budget, resource usage and other relevant performance information specified in the plan.

quote.para: (a) and (b) Depending on the functions of the organisational element concerned, the performance information in the supporting plan might include a mix of measures and/or standards as appropriate.Â For all departmental elements reviewed over the period August â November 2004, organisational performance was considered to compare favourably with the specified performance information.

I am also advised that in relation to the assessment for annual report preparation, each organisational element reports against the performance information set out for that element in the Portfolio Budget Statements for the corresponding financial year.

(a) and (b) For the 2003â04 reporting year, organisational performance could also be considered to compare favourably with the specified performance information.Â In the Departmentâs 2003â04 Annual Report the Secretary commented in his Review that the Department had made major contributions to the Governmentâs strategic directions.Â It was also noted in the overviews to the performance reports for the Departmentâs two outcomes that (the relevant departmental elements) made substantial contributions to Government initiatives, or made significant and substantial progress toward achieving the outcome.
